intro: Transberingia virgata, commonly known as the Alaska snowbell, is a flowering plant native to the Arctic and subarctic regions of North America. It is characterized by its showy, bell-shaped white flowers that bloom in late spring. The plant typically grows in moist, rocky soils and is often found in tundra and alpine environments. Its leaves are small, oval, and covered in a fine, white pubescence. Transberingia virgata plays an important role in pollination and serves as a food source for local wildlife.
